articles.title: Nigeria's Fela Kuti is first African musician honoured with Grammys Lifetime Achievement award
articles.summary: Nigeria’s Afrobeat legend Fela Kuti will be posthumously honored this weekend with a Grammys Lifetime Achievement Award, becoming the first African artist to receive the prestigious distinction.
articles.content:
Nigerian musician and composer Fela Anikulapo Kuti performs on September 13, 1986 at the "Party of Humankind" of the French Communist Party at La Courneuve in Paris, France.

Afrobeat legend Fela Kuti to make history as first African honoured with posthumous Grammy Lifetime Achievement Award. After a lifetime of clashes with successive powers in Nigeria, the recognition comes nearly three decades after Fela's death and long after his influence reshaped global music.

He is one of several artists getting the award at a ceremony in Los Angeles on Saturday, the eve of the main Grammys gala.

Others are Cher, Whitney Houston, Carlos Santana, Paul Simon and Chaka Khan.

In the 1970s, Fela the multi-instrumentalist and full-of-life performer invented Afrobeat: a mixture of jazz, funk and African rhythms.

That laid the groundwork for Afrobeats – a later genre that has attracted a global audience by blending traditional African rhythms with contemporary pop sounds, with its roots in Nigeria.

Two years ago the Grammys introduced the category of Best African Performance in 2024 and it has been dominated by Afrobeats artists, especially from Nigeria.

Watch moreRebellion Afrobeat: Growing up with Fela Kuti

Of the five nominees for the Best African performance this year, three are Nigerian Afrobeats singers, after another Nigerian, Tems, won last year.

"Fela's influence spans generations, inspiring artists such as Beyonce, Paul McCartney and Thom Yorke, and shaping modern Nigerian Afrobeats," said a citation on the Grammys list of this year's honourees.

Known also as the "Black President", the activist and legendary musician, died in 1997 at the age of 58.

His legacy lives on through his sons, Femi Kuti and Seun Kuti, and grandson Made.

"This acknowledgment coming at this time when all three of us are present. It feels wonderful," Grammy-nominated Made Kuti said.

"It feels wonderful that all of us are still practicing Afrobeat, still taking the legacy as far as we can take it."

'Better later than never'

Yemisi Ransome-Kuti, Fela's first cousin and head of the family, said on Friday the award was "a celebration for the African people and they should take (it).. as their award. Another African is being celebrated."

"But we also want to send a message to those who are giving these acknowledgements, please ...not wait till people are dead," she said.

As to what would have been Fela's reaction, Ransome-Kuti said: "I'm sure he would have said better late than never" although "in his lifetime he was not particularly interested in being recognised in the external world, particularly the western world".

Read moreThe Bright Side: French-Nigerian artists join forces to create future hits

Fela was arrested frequently by military governments during his career, sometimes for political activism and sometimes also on allegations of theft, which he denied.

His first brush with the law dated back to 1974 when he released his famous album "Zombie", generally considered by the military authorities in power as a diatribe levelled at them.

His songs were long, defiant and explicitly anti-governments in power and anti-corruption.

His manager, Rikki Stein, speaking on the phone from Los Angeles where he will join the Kuti family at the ceremony, was confident the award would "significantly uplift Fela's music".

"Fifty albums out there. I'm sure it's going to continue onward and upward."

"An increasing number of people what weren't even born when Fela died are expressing interest in listening to Fela's music and hopefully Fela's message," he said

(FRANCE 24 with AFP)

articles.personality_title: Fela Kuti becomes first African musician to receive Grammy Lifetime Achievement Award
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – Fela Kuti was a Nigerian musician who created Afrobeat, a music style mixing jazz, funk, and African rhythms. He used his music to speak out against corruption and government problems in Nigeria. He passed away in 1997 but left a big influence on music worldwide.

**What happened** – This weekend, Fela Kuti will be honored with a Grammy Lifetime Achievement Award. This is the first time an African artist has received this special award. The ceremony will take place in Los Angeles, alongside other famous musicians like Cher and Carlos Santana.

**Impact** – This award shows how important Fela’s music has been for many people, including famous artists like Beyoncé and Paul McCartney. His style helped start Afrobeats, a popular music genre today, especially in Nigeria. The award also celebrates African culture and music on a global stage.

**What’s next step** – Fela’s sons and grandson, who also make Afrobeat music, will continue his legacy. The award might inspire more people to discover and enjoy Fela’s music and the Afrobeat style he created. It also highlights growing recognition for African artists at the Grammys.

**One-sentence takeaway** – Fela Kuti’s groundbreaking music earned him the first Grammy Lifetime Achievement Award given to an African artist, celebrating his lasting impact on global music.

articles.personality_title_es: Fela Kuti se convierte en el primer músico africano en recibir el Grammy Lifetime Achievement Award
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – Fela Kuti fue un músico nigeriano que creó el Afrobeat, un estilo musical que mezcla jazz, funk y ritmos africanos. Usaba su música para hablar contra la corrupción y los problemas políticos en Nigeria. Murió en 1997, pero su influencia musical es mundial.

**Qué pasó** – Este fin de semana, Fela Kuti será honrado con un Grammy Lifetime Achievement Award. Es la primera vez que un artista africano recibe este premio especial. La ceremonia será en Los Ángeles, junto a otros músicos famosos como Cher y Carlos Santana.

**Impacto** – Este premio muestra lo importante que ha sido la música de Fela para muchas personas, incluyendo artistas famosos como Beyoncé y Paul McCartney. Su estilo ayudó a crear el Afrobeats, un género muy popular hoy, especialmente en Nigeria. El premio también celebra la cultura y música africanas en todo el mundo.

**Próximo paso** – Los hijos y el nieto de Fela, que también hacen música Afrobeat, continuarán su legado. El premio puede inspirar a más personas a descubrir y disfrutar la música de Fela y el estilo Afrobeat que creó. También muestra un mayor reconocimiento para los artistas africanos en los Grammys.

**Resumen en una frase** – La música innovadora de Fela Kuti le valió el primer Grammy Lifetime Achievement Award para un artista africano, celebrando su impacto duradero en la música global.
